title: World Leaders to Discuss Next Steps at U.N. Climate Summit
text:
World leaders are set to convene at the United Nations to discuss the next steps in the global effort to slow the warming of the planet.

Monday’s climate summit is designed to generate momentum around meeting the goals of the 2015 Paris accord, which aims to limit global temperature increases to less than 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Fahrenheit).

Delegates aren’t expected to hammer out new agreements during the one-day event. Instead, more than 60 countries, as well as business leaders and other government officials, are set to outline the measures they are taking to combat climate change. Key topics include phasing out coal and becoming carbon neutral by midcentury.

The U.S., which has vowed to leave the climate pact, isn’t slated to take the stage Monday. Among those scheduled to speak are Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi and German Chancellor Angela Merkel.

The summit follows youth climate strikes across the globe Friday, and is accompanied by a series of industry and investor events throughout the week that are focused on adopting more-sustainable business practices.

“What is clear is that we are not moving fast enough and we need to accelerate, and so we are here to push, push, push, push,” U.N. Secretary-General António Guterres told reporters Friday.

The average global temperature already is 1.1 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, according to World Meteorological Organization estimates.

Related Video At the U.N General Assembly, Brazil’s President Jair Bolsonaro plans to address concerns about deforestation, the Amazon fires and economic development in his country. WSJ’s Jason Bellini previewed the topics with Brazilian Environment Minister Ricardo Salles. Photo: Getty

Ms. Merkel unveiled a package of new climate policies last week that includes electric vehicle subsidies and a price on carbon dioxide emissions.

The European Union had hoped to marshal support from all 28 member states for achieving carbon neutrality by 2050, a top U.N. objective, but has yet to reach consensus.

While no Trump administration officials are set to speak, Maine Gov. Janet Mills, who recently signed a bill into law targeting an 80% reduction in the state’s greenhouse-gas emissions by 2050, is on tap to talk. The U.N. has invited several local and regional officials tackling climate change around the world, to demonstrate that action is happening at all levels.

“People can only speak if they come with positive steps, so there is a kind of a ticket,” Mr. Guterres said. “For bad news, don’t come.”

Escalating tensions in the Middle East following strikes earlier this month that hobbled top Saudi Arabian oil facilities, as well as trade conflicts between the U.S. and China, are expected to loom large over the event, which precedes the start of general debate at the annual U.N. General Assembly.

“We are witnessing simultaneously global warming and global political warming, and the two things are combined and making our life more difficult,” Mr. Guterres said.

—Emre Peker contributed to this article.

Write to Rebecca Elliott at rebecca.elliott@wsj.com
description: World leaders are set to convene at the United Nations to discuss the next steps in the global effort to slow the warming of the planet.
